title: A Semantic Data Grid for Satellite Mission Quality Analysis
segmentation: OK, so my name is Reuben right?

I work for a company called Demo Space where active in many areas to do with space systems all the way from planning future missions and feasibility studies up to operational systems, controlling satellites and the monitoring satellites.

What I'm going to talk about today is a research project we were involved in as part of an tigrid which was defining as it says here, a semantic data grid for satellite mission quality analysis, and I'll run through what we did and what result.
We found.
In terms of structure, I'm going to try and explain the rather lengthy title and what it really means to do satellite mission quality analysis.
I'll show you what it is, what kind of data we're working with.
And then explain what a semantic grid is and how we developed one.

And then at the more practical end of things, we're looking at how we can query information, how we can generate reports on information, and I'll talk you through some of the tools we used to do that, and then we'll show you the evaluation we had of the approach that we came up with.
And if the results that we produced.
So I think there's a sort of running theme in these three about senses and getting information from sensors.
What we do with Earth observation satellites is have some sensors that we access.
They just happen to be in orbit quite a long way away and quite hard to change once they're up there.
But in essence, and Earth observation, satellite is a camera.
We can send instructions to asking it to point in different directions, move to different modes, and two of course acquire data.
Hum.
This particular picture satellite is the one that we we use data from.
It's called envious at.
I think it's the largest Earth observation satellites up at the moment run by Lisa Ann.
It has 10 different instruments on it, most of which have multiple different modes.
They can be in.
And.
The system of course has only a certain amount of storage within it, and it needs to contact.
We've got pictured below the ground station.
This is 1 in Corona up in the Arctic Circle, and that's communication is 2 way we need to send planned capture information up to the satellite so it knows when to change.
Mode wins change pointing when to acquire information and information then has to come back down from the satellite to the ground station, which is what we call product data.
Essentially, it's the captured data.
Um?

Once we have that information back down on the ground, we then have we feed it back into to what we call the ground segment, which is just a very small schematic down there showing that the number of systems that interact, plan and operate at a satellite mission.
The data is processed in a number of different stages.
Obviously what we get down from the satellite is very raw binary packets.
These need to be assembled to get the actual product files.
The images that were captured.

And then we can do things like adding geographical information to workout where the satellite was pointing at the time to interpret different layers of information that we might want to combine from multiple different instruments.
And we transferred.
We do this in a number of stages until we get to what we call level two data which is suitable for scientific analysis.
So within what we call the ground segment, everything that isn't up in space.
We've got a number of different systems, a number of different facilities, often there in different parts of the world, and there certainly built and operated by different teams of people.
So we have mission planning whose job it is to work out what the satellites going to do.
So they're going to receive information from scientists or meteorologists about what information they need.
We've got flight operations.
You handle the nitty gritty of keeping track of where the satellite is, where it needs to be.
Acquisition stations for getting information down, processing, and then there's a number of extra things that need to be done.
Once we've got the information we've got to archive, it would disseminate it to the interesting interested parties, and so on.
This is typical in aerospace that we have a complex system where different parts of it would have been built separately.
And a lot of the information is is transferred by files.
It's fairly old technology in many ways, but it's tried and tested and that's what's quite important.
A lot of the time with with aerospace information.
Some of these files, obviously, in particular the product files, are very large and we're talking gigabytes of data and we can have thousands of acquisitions but for orbit.

Quality analysis is basically carried out by receiving copies of these files that are passed between them and trying to extract information from them to work out if everything is operating as it should be.
If the plans make sense if the products match up to the plans.
If the products are being processed correctly or if information is being lost somewhere and this is done using a bespoke system developed called Quark at Present and Clark is a cord of core system.
That's tailored for each individual mission like that comes along because there were always changes.

Quite produces an awful lot of reports designed to check different elements of the acquisition, and they sent out to the different people who need to know about the information can do the analysis on it.
However, this basically a a problem of floor with the approach of having these these designed reports to monitor the system, and that's what we're really looking for is anomalies.
We're looking for things that went wrong.
There's that Donald Rumsfeld phrase about unknown unknowns.
It's it's the things we don't know that are the problems.
So ideally what we would like is a much more flexible system where we can go in and query the data.
And if we've got questions the turn around time from the operational scientists to the.

The people managing the system can be minutes rather than months as it is at present, so the idea was to as part of the integrated project to use this as a essentially a use case for what we call a semantic data grid to capture all this information and to allow access to it in much more flexible ways.
So this is what we built and I'll be going through.
Obviously in all the details, so don't worry too much about their bewildering number of acronyms and icons and so on, but I'll just go through quickly.
The stage is the numbered stages here, which show what is achieved.
What is achieved by the system?
So we start in the top left corner where we're able to select various files that need to be reported upon the need to be got into the system.
We can get summaries of files if they're particularly large, and we can essentially create annotations or add metadata to do with these product files.
So what we're doing is logging them into the system.
We use an ontology for structuring them with storing as RDF with storing within something called Atlas.
This is a peer to peer organized RDF storage system, so we're distributing that storage over a large number of machines.
Just to look at the geography.
That's why there's a map in the middle there.
This system we have query interfaces in Manchester.
We've got information in the ontologies and some of the products in Madrid.
We've got information access for Atlas via servers in Athens and we've got storage distributed over a data grid called Ever Lab, which has hundreds of nodes all over Europe.
So we're demonstrating really how distributed we can make this system and still have everything hooked up.
Neatly.
To go to the other end of it quickly, then we have to be able to query this data.
We want to get information back out the system.
We're not just putting it into an archive, so we have a number of query clients which work to translate what the user needs to know across into RDF query languages.
And then there's ways that we want to process that information before giving it back to the users to make it as useful as possible.
So I'll just talk then a little bit of.
About what we mean by a semantic grid.
So grid systems grid computing is distributed computing.

Obviously I'm going to focus more in this conference talking about the semantics of what we built, but we're building on top of grid systems using something called globis, which is a very common toolkit for building grid systems.
There are things like grid FTP.
There are ways of doing remote procedure calls over grid systems, and we feel is as a whole that in the same way that the semantic web makes a lot of sense and gains a lot over.
Usual web semantic grid has a lot of advantages over the usual grid technologies.
So we're using and some of the partners in Manchester.
Very influential in defining what we call the S ogsa architecture.
This is a semantically enabled grid grid systems architecture for deploying systems on the grid that will need to talk to each other and will need to talk in a semantically meaningful way.
So we have within the grid what we call grid entities, which are essentially anything that exists on the grid that can be identified.
Could be data systems, anything.
As a specific sort of those, we have knowledge entities which could be anything from an ontology or a few RDF triples, or just a simple tag or a description.
It's essentially it's it's metadata that exists within within the grid system, and then we define what we call semantic bindings which are.
Essentially a just a link between a knowledge entity and and any grid entity, so it's assigning metadata to a particular object.
Um?

Crucially, we then access them by what we call semantic provisioning services, which are essentially semantically aware services for managing these knowledge entities and the semantic bindings about them.
One crucial element of all of this is making these semantic bindings themselves.
They the tribu shun of metadata, 2 items, first class citizens.
So it's not just a sort of adjunct to the data, it's treated as the data itself.
It can have metadata assigned to it.
It can have an identity.
It has a life cycle.
It has provenance information and this gives an awful lot more flexibility by by making those things.
So we say first class citizens.
So what we built was these semantically aware grid services for annotating information for storing the information and then for querying that information.
So I'll just go through those phases to explain what this is.
When does?
Annotation, then we.
This was a research project and we obviously had to limit our scope and in certain ways.

So what we decided to work with where the plan files which define what we want the satellite to do and the product files, which is the data coming back down from the satellite or after various stages of processing.
So we're working with these files.
Project files in particular.
As I said, can be very large.
They can be about 60 gigabytes or so.
We really only need a few kilobytes from that sort of header section in the file name containing the metadata we need to monitor here.

So we use something called on to DSI for extracting that information we needed to have access to the defined satellites ontology in order for checking the consistency of our data, and for allowing it to be stored.
Inside the system we have something called the TFs create Access bridge which essentially allows these semantic binding service access to the ontology through the grid.
A system called Greek KP.
I was creating annotations are meta data and then these semantic binding service manages them, assigns them to the particular entity I files themselves or the events.

The system is also managing updates to plan files because we're managing the metadata itself as an object with a lifestyle Providence were able to say OK, this person is already submitted a plan file.
They submitted a plan for what they think the satellite should do.
Tomorrow.
They submitted it 2 weeks ago.
However, something's changed now got a new plan filed as there's a new plan that's been sent up to the satellite.
We obviously need to make sure that our system is reporting on the plan file as it was sent to the satellite.
I mean, for example when there was a hurricane Hurricane Ike, I think was approaching the coast in Texas.
They had to evacuate the Johnson Space Center in Houston and transfer some operations elsewhere.
So satellite needs to be told where which ground station it's going to be sending information to.
That's the kind of thing that can happen later on, or if there's a say, a volcanic eruption, we may want satellites to be looking at that and canceling their sort of baseline acquisition.
So we get late changes to plans, and we needed to be able to manage those within the system.
The key thing really that we we managed with the annotation is extracting what was usually completely implicit.

Metadata just orders, codes or whatever within these files and making it explicit and tying it into an ontology so that we could do some basic reasoning over it and have much more flexible access to it.
So I'll just walk through.
A very simple example.
Really, this is what a product filename looks like.

It's basically meaningless, and until you know what you're you're looking at, so within space systems, what we get given to work with are called interface control documents, and they define what each of the what the file name will have to be.
So for example, we will be given tables like this that will tell us this is how the product file name needs to be built up.
And we could use these rules to then define the rules for extracting the information, the metadata making it explicit.
So, for example, we would know that the instrument will be stored in those first few characters.
We would know that the sensing start time would be encoded as shown here, and we also know the rules for that.
Incidentally, we had to make conversions.
There are many, many different time systems.
You wouldn't believe the number of standards that people in the space industry half the time.
We had to convert all of the ones here.

Given is essentially dates and then times across to what we call modified Julian Date 2000, which is the number of seconds that have passed since the start of the year 2000 and that gives us a sort of baseline to work off.
It's it's easier for systems to work that way than to constantly be fiddling around with leap years and so on, but because things are complicated, there are quite specific algorithms for that.
There are leap seconds assigned every now and then that either get added or subtracted from the year.
So we didn't actually have some in-house algorithms that already used, and we built a wrapper to make them into a soap web service so that we could convert those.
What we end up with is good old RDF and we can see here where we've got the various different pieces of information we may have extracted.
So, for example, the sensing start and stop time as modified Julian date 2000.
The plan event identifier and we've also got which instrument it was executed by and I'll come back to that later to show you how we how we obtained.
Information, so this is the ontology as built technically.
It's not really owl in space, it's out of space.
Every bit matters when you're sending information up and down, so there's no actual RDF floating around in space I'm afraid.
But this is our our structure for how we're going to be able to talk about these systems and be able to analyze the various.
The working of the system.
We also this is a visualization using the neon toolkits, which I know is involved in this conference.

We developed the ontology in Protege another tool we found quite useful when talking to domain experts and when seeing what we had in the data was I service to browse the actual RDF of the information.
As captured it would show us what we had was linked to what.
I'm.
OK, so.
Once we've extracted the information, we've got RDF.
Obviously we want to be storing it somewhere.
As I said, we had.
This system was developed by the University of Athens.
Could Atlas for doing distributed RDF storage.

So we produced web forms that would.
Show us.
That we could replicate the current functionality and then we could work on extending it.
This.
An example here than of semantic querying, so this is, I mean kind of basic stuff for us, but it's quite important for the space industry.
This kind of shift, so a couple of little snippets of sparkle up here.
The first one is matching on event identifiers.
That's essentially the big long filename.
Their matching having RA for the radar altimeter, but when we were doing the annotations they said we could link directly across that.
We knew that certain identifiers were related to certain instruments, so we knew that everything tagged with RA two in the.
Identify would actually be the radar altimeter.
Therefore we could shift our queries from the simple regex based ones that we had initially up to talking directly about instruments.
It's a simple change, but the flexibility we get, it gives us things like we can define different event types that use the same instrument if we want to use it for calibrating.

Also, if we add in extra data about instruments, we can write our queries an entirely new level so we can make sure we can try and analyze situations where a certain wattage of power was being drawn and if that correlates with some problems, then you know that gives us something to investigate.
So.
One issue we had once we've done some basic reports that the monitor.
As the current system does was to see how quickly we could evolve new reports, how flexibly we could actually make this so we came up with a little tool that was based off JSP.
The idea being that a report designer who knows Sparkle knows about ontologies is able to build up a web form based reports very quickly.
For an ordinary users to actually use.
So the idea here is that this is a base sparkle query for the report that will be run with various.
Nation provided by the user.
So if you look at this snippet of sparkle, we've got some things prefixed with two question marks.
That's that's bad form in sparkle, but what it's use.

For is that the report designer is able to say that for these particular values, the user is going to provide the information and it gives the idea of what the how the user is going to be prompted for it.
So we had date Fields, dropdown list text and so on, and then again at the bottom.
Here we we need to tell how we want the results to be presented to the user.
So we came up with a different number of graph types that could be generated.
So we would run that the GSP would just creates what this is a HTML web form should be immediately deployed on the same web server and then the user can be presented with this.

The user can provide some data that will be combined with the sort of can sparkle query, then the processing of the results will generate for example this where we've got tabular results from the various things that sparkle returns and also a graphical plots trading overlapping.
I have two different sorts of events here.
It's an instrument used in planning.
So I'll go through now.
Really, the problems in the advantages we found with this.
One of our key problems really was just the amount of time and investment of time it took deploying grid technologies.
They that there was just quite a lot of overhead to manage this.
Another one is that the different legacy data formats we have to work with have very specific data types.
For example the time ones I mentioned.

A third one is that missions have similar interfaces and files, but often there are small customizations, so there's work to be done to make sure that we've actually captured what this particular mission cares about.
And the last is is very common I'm afraid.
But in the aerospace industry, which is inertia?
People are very unwilling to change systems that work that have components that they don't have access to.
So when we know every side is up there and we're not going to go up there and change its its firmware or anything, people are very wary of changing anything on the ground that interacts with that.
But what we found is is by demonstrating the use of this approach.
The agency has been much keener on building new systems using semantic technology and coming up with future improvements to systems.
So looking at the advantages, the key ones in terms of the process that we went through with the integration of data obviously helped by ontology.
We were able to communicate well between the different people involved and users get advantages because they don't need to be involved until they're actually running reports.

And in terms of the results, we've got flexible querying of the data from from many different sources, so we've got these systems producing different sorts of files were able to query that altogether, tide together with a single ontology, everything is virtualized for the user we're storing in 100 machines around Europe, they just have a simple web access in support for the life cycle of the data, and it was a good clear demonstration that we're able to use to show this industry what what we can do.
In the future, how we can make things?
So thank you very much and any questions.
Well, first of all I want to say this.
This has been a very good industry track in general and in this application specifically this demo is 1 where I've had trouble with space.
I've worked with space industry for some time and date architects visionary architects have been giving me the question of relevance.
Huawei semantic technology.
You know this is an excellent example of why it is relevant.

In the field against the traditional data architecture, approaches that.
Those guys are having trouble letting go of and looking toward new solutions.
OK, so yeah, in terms of getting this kind of system into deployment, I'm afraid all I can say is I'm waiting with just as much bated breath as you are.
We this demonstration is happened and when we now starting to see invitations to tender and so on, there are clearly showing that the messages is hitting home, so we are still.
I'm afraid in at the level of needing to demonstrate why these things are worth doing, but we already have direct work coming down from East of the European Space Agency.
To work on semantic levels above their systems to work on unifying different systems.
When I'm involved in is all about the access to different missions via common protocols, so the idea is it could be any submission providing data.
It could be demos his own satellite that we have that will provide the data could be a set of unmanned aerial vehicles flying around just above the surface.
Ways to access these things altogether are being worked on, and I think increasingly the.
The ideas that are coming down to us from Isa.
To do with using.
Using semantics or they don't generally use the word, but using common interfaces using common descriptions to make it easier to to work between systems and to reuse systems.
Do you know if this has been demonstrated to the US satellite industry in and others in the?
I don't know.
In the USI may not be very happy.
Fair to point you at some more resource is if there's people you think could see this, I'd like you to give your card out to people and have them in certain cases another take a closer look.
OK, yeah.
Do you have any other questions?
OK, so thank you, Ruben.

Given is essentially dates and then times across to what we call modified Julian Date 2000, which is the number of seconds that have passed since the start of the year 2000 and that gives us a sort of baseline to work off.

There are leap seconds assigned every now and then that either get added or subtracted from the year.

Really, the problems in the advantages we found with this.
One of our key problems really was just the amount of time and investment of time it took deploying grid technologies.
They that there was just quite a lot of overhead to manage this.
Another one is that the different legacy data formats we have to work with have very specific data types.
For example the time ones I mentioned.

A third one is that missions have similar interfaces and files, but often there are small customizations, so there's work to be done to make sure that we've actually captured what this particular mission cares about.
And the last is is very common I'm afraid.
But in the aerospace industry, which is inertia?
People are very unwilling to change systems that work that have components that they don't have access to.
So when we know every side is up there and we're not going to go up there and change its its firmware or anything, people are very wary of changing anything on the ground that interacts with that.
But what we found is is by demonstrating the use of this approach.
The agency has been much keener on building new systems using semantic technology and coming up with future improvements to systems.
So looking at the advantages, the key ones in terms of the process that we went through with the integration of data obviously helped by ontology.
We were able to communicate well between the different people involved and users get advantages because they don't need to be involved until they're actually running reports.

And in terms of the results, we've got flexible querying of the data from from many different sources, so we've got these systems producing different sorts of files were able to query that altogether, tide together with a single ontology, everything is virtualized for the user we're storing in 100 machines around Europe, they just have a simple web access in support for the life cycle of the data, and it was a good clear demonstration that we're able to use to show this industry what what we can do.
